conclusion: Analyze the p-V diagram to determine work done by the gas from A to B and B to C, then use the first law of thermodynamics to find heat transferred.
The image shows a p-V diagram for an ideal gas with points A, B, and C. Path A to B is vertical (isothermal), and B to C is horizontal (isobaric). Temperature at A is 27°C.
Process A to B is isothermal, so work done W_A to B is calculated using W = nRT ln(V_B/V_A).
Convert temperature 27°C to Kelvin: T = 300.15 K.
Diagram shows V_A = 6 x 10^-3 m^3 and V_B = 2 x 10^-3 m^3.
Calculate W_A to B = nR x 300.15 ln(2/6).
Process B to C is isobaric, work done W_B to C = p x ΔV = p x (V_C - V_B).
From the diagram, V_C = 2 x 10^-3 m^3, and p = 3 x 10^5 Pa.
Calculate W_B to C = 3 x 10^5 x (2 - 2) = 0.
Total work done W_A to C = W_A to B + W_B to C = W_A to B.
Using first law of thermodynamics, Q = nC_v ΔT = nC_v (T_C - T_A).
